newsitem.title: USA: U.S. spot natgas erodes further ahead of weekend.
newsitem.headline: U.S. spot natgas erodes further ahead of weekend.

text.p: U.S. spot natgas prices for the weekend extended their losses Friday as forecasters called for below-normal temperatures in the East and in Texas, industry sources said.

Louisiana Gulf Coast swing prices fell by another five cents to the $1.90-1.95 per million British thermal units area due to the normal drop in weekend demand coupled with cooler temperatures in both the production and market areas.
Early swing values at Henry Hub, La., were in the high-$1.90s, but then eased into the $1.93-1.95 range as the end of the nomination period neared.

Traders said cloud cover in Texas from Hurricane Dolly resulted in a weaker demand and thereby put downward pressure on prices. Traders reported closing most deals in the mid-to-high $1.80s, down more than five cents.
In the Midcontinent, prices slipped into the low-to-mid $1.70s, down about five to six cents from Thursday's levels.

The languishing Texas demand also pressured Permian prices lower into the mid-to-high $1.60s. However, southern California border values gained about two cents because of the impending above-normal temperatures to the West Coast.
Forecasters said the storm brewing in the Atlantic Ocean, named Edouard, may be upgraded to a hurricane later today as it heads toward land.
